metadata.case_name: Bhagwati Saran and Sushila Devi v. State

facts.text: Appellants are Bhagwati Saran (husband, manager) and Sushila Devi (wife, proprietor) of firm Balwanta Devi Sushila Devi, a registered stockholder in Sultanpur, Uttar Pradesh.

Police report dated August 20, 1955, by officer in charge of Police Station Sultanpur under Section 11B Iron Steel Control Order, 1941, alleging Bhagwati Saran sold iron bars above control rate, issued fictitious receipts.
Information given to D.M. Sultanpur by munim Kalapnath leading to case registration.
S.P. ordered charge-sheet under s.8 Essential Commodities Ordinance 1955; charge-sheet under s.11-B(iii) Iron Steel Control Order 1941 r/w s.8 Ordinance against both accused.
Judicial Magistrate registered case, issued summons September 16, 1955; case called September 30, 1955.

Accused examined under s.364 CrPC on March 23, 1956; charge framed March 24, 1956: sold 11 cwt 12 lb iron bars on Jan 11, 1952; 3 cwt on Feb 18, 1952; 1 cwt on Feb 26, 1952 at Rs.21-13-9 per cwt exceeding controlled rate Rs.21-2-4 per cwt as per notification July 1, 1952, under s.7 Essential Supplies Temp Powers Act 1946 r/w s.11B(iii) Control Order.
Sessions Judge, Sultanpur, reference to High Court recommending quashing charge due to defect in police report under s.11 Act.
Allahabad High Court Single Judge disagreed on s.11, referred cl.11-B constitutionality to Division Bench; Division Bench upheld; Single Judge dismissed reference.

legal_issues.text: Whether police report dated August 20, 1955, satisfied requirements of s.11 Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946 by setting out facts constituting offence.
Whether notification dated July 1, 1952, fixing maximum prices was ultra vires cl.11-B(1) Iron Steel Control Order, 1941.
Whether notification dated July 1, 1952, was discriminatory violating Art.14 Constitution.
Whether cl.11-B Control Order violated Art.19(1)(g) Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Police report did not contain facts constituting offence as required by s.11 Act: no dates, quantities, buyers, category of iron/steel, precise max price, excess amount.
Notification July 1, 1952 ultra vires cl.11-B(1): omitted non-registered producers; did not include registered stockholders in column II, either excluded or put in residual column III.
Notification discriminatory under Art.14: controlled vs registered stockholders - credit facilities and cutting charges allowed to controlled but not registered.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14 Constitution; General/Special Conditions in price circular

court_reasoning.text: No need to hear respondent as appellants' contentions without merit.

Notification within cl.11-B(1): all producers registered, no omission; registered stockholders in column III as 'all other persons'; classification between controlled (wholesale) and registered (retail) stockholders rational, benefits appellants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Controller can sub-classify within categories for policy of reasonable prices.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination under Art.14: differentiation not per se discrimination; no material shows irrationality in credit/cutting charges; incidentals not quantifiable fixed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption against discrimination; appellants benefited by classification.

court_reasoning.text: cl.11-B constitutionality upheld in Union of India v. Bhana Mal.
s.11 report sufficient: states contravention of notification by sales above max prices; details emerge later at charge/trial; function is to record public servant's satisfaction, not charge-sheet.

holdings.text: Notification July 1, 1952 valid and within powers under cl.11-B(1); not discriminatory.
Police report complies with s.11 Act.
cl.11-B not violative of Art.19(1)(g) or Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Messrs. Bhana Mal Gulzari Mal
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld constitutionality of cl.11-B Control Order; similar notification upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. N. G. Chatterji v. Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Report too vague, unlike present case.
Report merely stated offence without facts, unlike present.

statutes_cited.name: Iron and Steel (Control of Production and Distribution) Order, 1941
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to fix maximum prices; basis of prosecution and challenge.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of contravention; cognizance only on public servant's report stating facts.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to carry on business; equality; challenges to Control Order and notification.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld High Court order dismissing reference, held notification valid, police report compliant with s.11, directed prosecution to continue.

key_quotes.text: Having heard the learned Counsel for the appellants in full we did not consider it necessary to call on the respondent since, we were clearly of the opinion that the contentions raised in the appeal possessed no merit.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Indicates court's preliminary view dismissing appeal.

key_quotes.text: The purpose and policy of the enactment is to ensure that an essential commodity like iron and steel is made available, to the consumer at reasonable prices and in the achievement of this objective classification of producers or of other stockholders based upon rational grounds would obviously be within the power of the Controller.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Differentiation could never per se be discrimination, nor is there any presumption that the adoption of different rules for groups differently situated is unequal treatment violative of Art. 14.
key_quotes.speaker: court
